docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican nominee for President, has told other senators that he will try to amend a bipartisan health insurance bill to encourage medical savings accounts, a proposal that puts him squarely at odds with President Clinton. The proposal, strongly supported by conservative Republicans, would create tax incentives for people to establish such savings accounts to pay medical expenses, as an alternative to standard health insurance.

headline.main: Dole Plan on Health Bill May Encounter Resistance

docs.lead_paragraph: A Senate committee today approved a bill that would require health plans to cover at least 48 hours of hospital care for mothers and their newborn infants. The measure is supported by many doctors, but is opposed by many health maintenance organizations, which see it as a precedent for the Government to dictate benefits. The Committee on Labor and Human Resources approved the bill by a vote of 14 to 2.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Logical Loopholes" (Op-Ed, April 14): We should be grateful to Leo Katz for his discovery of a hitherto unknown "fact of morality," that "many a forbidden result is no longer forbidden if we get to it in the right way." Those among us who have thought that forbidden results were forbidden because they were "wrong" or morally unacceptable can take heart, knowing that if we should need to do away with our neighbor, or defraud the Medicare system, or pursue some other forbidden result, all we need do is find the right way, or the right lawyer.

headline.main: Medicaid Loopholes Are for Good Reason;Dubious Morality

docs.lead_paragraph: When I heard that Mary Matalin was joining the Dole campaign, where she could throw poison darts and blow kisses to James Carville over at the Clinton campaign, I muttered darkly, "Not that again." But my reaction to a reprise of the Romeo-and-Juliet routine that spawned a book, a movie, a "Meet the Press" gig, pricey lectures and a baby girl was mild compared with the livid quotes of G.O.P. state chairmen in The Washington Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Insurance Commissioner, Elizabeth Randall, announced new regulations yesterday barring health and life insurance companies from inquiring whether applicants have ever been victims of domestic violence. The new rules will also prohibit companies from limiting or excluding benefits when a loss results from battering. The regulations were inspired by reports that at least two companies included questions about domestic violence on applications, Ms. Randall said.

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Shift on Insurance Inquiries

docs.lead_paragraph: When a bypass operation last January failed to mend Frank Borino's heart, his doctors arranged for him to get an assisting device installed while he waited for a heart transplant. Mr. Borino, of Jersey City, contended in a lawsuit filed last month that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey agreed to pay for the transplant but reneged. Today, two Assembly Democrats, Loretta Weinberg of Teaneck and William J. Pascrell of Paterson, planned to ask the State Insurance Department to examine whether policies like Mr. Bodino's provide adequate coverage.

headline.main: Breach of Promise Suit Is Filed

keywords.value: BLUE CROSS AND BLUE SHIELD OF NEW JERSEY

docs.lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Hospital Association, a trade organization that represents most of the state's hospitals, filed a lawsuit against the state today, seeking payment for free medical treatment to the uninsured. New Jersey was supposed to have sent out its third round of checks today to reimburse 84 hospitals around the state for providing the free medical care. The state distributed $388 million to hospitals last year by dipping into the unemployment insurance fund, but the state's authority to continue using the fund expired on Dec. 31. Attempts to come up with a new financing plan, including the raising of the cigarette tax, have failed to gain legislative approval.

headline.main: Hospitals Sue New Jersey to Recover Millions Spent to Treat the Poor

docs.lead_paragraph: A coalition of the largest municipal labor unions filed suit yesterday against the Giuliani administration, charging that city budget cuts were illegally shortchanging the public hospital system. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said the city has fallen $791 million short in its obligations to the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the city agency that runs the 11 municipal hospitals. The unions, which have thousands of jobs at risk if the city continues to shrink the hospital system, are asking for a court order to force the city to make up the shortfall.

headline.main: Unions Sue City on Hospital Financing

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders have chosen today, tax day, to stage a vote on an irresponsible measure that would amend the Constitution to require two-thirds majorities in both houses of Congress to raise taxes. The Republican sponsors know they lack the votes to approve the amendment. They simply want to trap the Democrats into opposing an anti-tax measure during an election year. The Republicans discredit themselves in two ways. First, they are trifling with the Constitution -- this proposed amendment has not been approved by appropriate Congressional committees. Second, as a purely practical matter, such an amendment would make it more difficult than it is now for Congress to choose responsible budget options.
